item.title: Food
item.author: false
item.description: Food (음식) 물 = water 밥 = rice 야채 = vegetables 과일 = fruit 고기 = meat 빵 = bread 해산물 = seafood 생선 = fish 두부 = Tofu 계란 = Eggs 치즈 = Cheese 반찬 = Side dishes Meals 아침 식사 = Breakfast 점심 식사 = Lunch 간식 = Snack 저녁 식사 = Dinner 후식 = Dessert Utencils 포크 = Fork 칼 = Knife 숟가락 = Spoon 젓가락 = Chopsticks

item.title: People
item.author: false
item.description: 어른 =adult 아가 = baby 아이들 = children 남자 = man 여자 = woman 소년 = boy 소녀 = girl 가족 = family 부모님 = parents 엄마 = mother 아버지 = father 딸 = daughter 아들 = son 언니 = older sister (of a girl) 누나 = older sister (of a boy) 오빠 = brother (of a girl) 형 = older brother (of a boy) 동생 = younger sibling 남동생 = younger brother

item.title: Conjunctions
item.author: false
item.description: Conjunctions connect two sentences together. Here are the most common conjunctions in Korean: 그래서 = so, therefore 그리고 = and 하지만 = but, however 그련데 = but, however, by the way 그래도 = but, still

item.title: Places
item.author: false
item.description: 집 = home 화장실 = bathroom 침실 = bedroom 거실 = living room 부엌 = kitchen 사무실 = office 차고 = garage 밖의 = outside 공원 = park 은행 = bank 편의점 = convenience store 커피숍 = coffee shop 식당 = restaurant 서점 = bookstore 미용실 = hair salon 병원 = hospital 시장 = market 영화관 = movie theater 약국 = pharmacy 슈퍼마켓 = supermarket 빵집 = bakery* 백화점 = department store

item.title: 하다
item.author: false
item.description: Conjugation 하다 = to do 해요 = do 했어요 = did do 할 거예요 = will do 하고 싶어요 = want to do 하고 싶지 않아요 = don’t want to 하겠어요 = going to do it 할 수있어요= can do 할 수 없어요 = cannot do 해야 해요 = have to do 합시다! = let’s do it 하세요 = do it, please 해 주세요 = please do Negative Sentences 안 해요 = don’t do

item.title: Study Plan
item.author: false
item.description: Maxims: Consistency is paramount. 30 minutes of focused study everyday including reading, writing, listening, and speaking. Learn only what you can use now. Avoid specialized/sophisticated words. Create simple routines to make studying easy. Start by building a foundation of: 10 to 20 useful phrases that can be used daily. 400 to 500 most frequent nouns, verbs, adjectives, and adverbs. Question words. 2 or 3 sentence strucutures. Plan: Use paper flashcards. Apps and websites just lead to distraction.

item.title: 하세요 vs. 해 주세요
item.author: false
item.description: 해 주세요 = Please do this for me. 하세요 = Do this, please. 부탁합니다 = Thank you for agree to do this favor for me. 하세요 is used to order someone to do something. It’s literal translation is “please do” but it’s a very direct way of communicating. In English it would be like saying, “do this…please”. “하세요” is something you might hear when your boss asks you to perform a task.

item.title: 음료 vs. 음료수
item.author: false
item.description: 음료 = drink or beverage 음료수 = tasty beverage Not all Koreans agree that there’s a distinction between 음료 and 음료수. Most that I’ve spoken to claim, that the words are interchangable in most situations. But, all agreed that 음료 is a general term that refers to all kinds drinks and beverages. Things like water, beer, wine, coffee, tea, etc. For some, 음료수 is only used to refer to a drink that quenches thurst.

item.title: 물고기 vs. 생선
item.author: false
item.description: 물고기 = fish (living fish) 생선 = fish (to eat) 해산물 = seafood Both 물고기 and 생선 have the literally meaning of fish but they’re used in different contexts. 물고기 refers to a living fish and is used to refer to a broad range of swimming animials with spines and gills. Things like sharks, tuna, goldfish, etc. But a jellyfish or a starfish. 생선 refers to fish you eat. More specially, fish that have purposely been cuaght for eating, like the salmon on your dinner plate.

item.title: Question Words?
item.author: false
item.description: Yesterday I couldn’t remember the word 언제 (when) for some reason, so I thought I review several question words today. 누구 = who 뭐 = what 언제 = when 어디 = where 왜 = why 어떻게 = how 무슨 = which 얼마 = how much 몇 = how many And some sentences for 언제: 언제 했어요? (When did you do it?) 언제 왔어요? (When did you come?) 언제 일어나요? (When did you get up?
